review.title: Interacting with Massive Behavioral Data
review.abstract: In this short paper, we propose the split-diffuse (SD) algorithm that takes the output of an existing word embedding algorithm, and distributes the data points uniformly across the visualization space. The result improves the perceivability and the interactability by the human.
histories: KDD 2016 Workshop on Interactive Data Exploration and Analytics
review.COMMENTS: KDD 2016 Workshop on Interactive Data Exploration and Analytics

metadata.title: Interacting with Massive Behavioral Data

sections.text: We use the SD algorithm to analyze user behavior through access protocols within the cyber security domain. The result, known as the topic grid, is a series of grids on different topics generated from the protocols. On the same set of grids, different behavioral metrics can be displayed over different time periods at different targets to provide visualization and interaction to human experts. Analysis, investigation and other types of interaction can be performed more efficiently on the topic grid than on the output of existing methods for dimension reduction. In addition to the area of cyber security, the topic grid can be applied to other areas such as e-commerce, credit card transactions, customer service to analyze behavior on a large scale. CCS concepts • Human-centered computing → Visual analytics; information visualization; keyword data visualization, human interaction, dimension reduction, risk management.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: If there are multiple measurements of the individual samples, the data in a high-dimensional space H is described by these measurements. In order to make these high-dimensional data points visible to humans, a word embedding technique (or dimension reduction) is used to map the data to a low-dimensional space L. Usually, L is a two-dimensional (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) space. The word embedding permission to create digital or printed copies of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without charge, provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial purposes and that copies bear this note and the full quotation on the first page. KDD 2016 Workshop on Interactive Data Exploration and DEFrancisco 2016 (DEA 14th Interactive Data) refers to the CA in IFrancisco, August 16, 2016.

sections.heading: 2. METHODS
sections.text: In order to make better use of the visualization space, we proposed dividing the data points evenly across the visualization space. In the meantime, the cloud of data points is deformed in the same space defined by the dimension reduction algorithm of choice. This deformation is referred to as S. In the meantime, it is desirable to maintain the point-by-point relationship maintained by the dimension reduction algorithm of choice. Our strategy in approaching this goal is prioritized as follows: 1. Points are uniformly prioritized after mapping p.2. The point-by-point topology is retained. S tries to keep point pj on the same side of point pi as before mapping.3. The point-by-point geometry is pursued as follows: If the pi is far from pj, S (pi) is far from S (pj).The algorithm we propose is called the split-diffuse (SD) algorithm (SD) algorithm that follows the strategies.

sections.heading: 3. INTERACTING WITH THE DATA
sections.text: The motivation to make better use of the visual space stems from the need to interact with enormous amounts of data. Consider the case that there are millions of elements that are shipped to a city each month. How can we easily observe the difference in monthly shipping patterns? Meanwhile, vectoring each element as a data point, with all the data points on a chart being hard to read. Instead, using clustering algorithms to group the points and show the representatives is a better way to present the shipping theme. However, with existing dimension reduction techniques (Figure 1 (a) - (d)), it is difficult to visually compare the difference and interact with the representative points for more detail. In our use case, we apply the SD algorithm to support the analysis of behavioral content in the cyber security domain. The goal of the system is to detect behavioral anomalies based on access data.

sections.heading: 4. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In addition to the domain of cyber security, the topic grids can be applied to other domains with free-form text protocols to analyze the behavior described by the protocols. Possible use cases include e-commerce, credit card transactions, customer service, or other behavioral data with large amounts of data to be analyzed. It is also possible to apply the topic grids to the structured data on which any cluster algorithm can generate cluster centers. Data points are then organized into these cluster centers, just as we use the topic to represent associated log entries.

sections.heading: 5. REFERENCES
sections.text: [1] M. Belkin and P. Niyogi. Laplacian eigenmaps fordimensionality reduction and data representation. Neural computation, 15 (6): 1373-1396, 2003. [2] P. Geurts, D. Ernst, and L. The London, Edinburgh, and DublinPhilosophical Magazine and Journal of Science, 2 (11): 559-572, 1901. [4] J. B. Tenenbaum, V. D. Silva, and J. C. Langford. A global geometric framework for nonlinear dimensionality reduction. Science, 290 (5500): 2319-2323, 2000. [5] W. S. Torgerson. Multidimensional scaling: I. theory and method. Psychometrics, 17 (4): 401-419, 1952. [6] Van der G. E. and Research, Hinsuaten, 25E-2685.

referenceMentions.context: For example, the multi-dimensional scaling (MDS) [5] M tries to preserve the distance between data points, during the mapping from H to L.
The stochastic neighbor embedding (SNE) [6] type of algorithms further emphasize the local relationship ahead of the global relationship.

Although we only present the results from t-SNE and MDS, the SD algorithm can be applied to outputs of other techniques such as the principal component analysis (PCA) [3], isomap [4], spectral embedding [1], and totally random trees embedding [2].

metadata.abstractText: In this short paper, we propose the split-diffuse (SD) algorithm that takes the output of an existing word embedding algorithm, and distributes the data points uniformly across the visualization space. The result improves the perceivability and the interactability by the human. We apply the SD algorithm to analyze the user behavior through access logs within the cyber security domain. The result, named the topic grids, is a set of grids on various topics generated from the logs. On the same set of grids, different behavioral metrics can be shown on different targets over different periods of time, to provide visualization and interaction to the human experts. Analysis, investigation, and other types of interaction can be performed on the topic grids more efficiently than on the output of existing dimension reduction methods. In addition to the cyber security domain, the topic grids can be further applied to other domains like e-commerce, credit card transaction, customer service to analyze the behavior in a large scale.
